review.title: Measuring Thematic Fit with Distributional Feature Overlap
review.abstract: In this paper, we introduce a new distributional method for modeling predicate-argument thematic fit judgments. We use a syntax-based DSM to build a prototypical representation of verb-specific roles: for every verb, we extract the most salient second order contexts for each of its roles (i.e. the most salient dimensions of typical role fillers), and then we compute thematic fit as a weighted overlap between the top features of candidate fillers and role prototypes. Our experiments show that our method consistently outperforms a baseline re-implementing a state-of-the-art system, and achieves better or comparable results to those reported in the literature for the other unsupervised systems. Moreover, it provides an explicit representation of the features characterizing verb-specific semantic roles.

More specifically, their gold standard consisted of the human judgments proposed by McRae et al. (1998) and Pado. sections.heading: 3 Methodology
sections.text: As reported by Sayeed et al. (2016), most work on unattended thematic adaptation estimation varies in the method used to construct the prototypes. (The semantic role prototypes are usually a vector achieved by averaging the most typical fillers, and the plausibility of new fillers depends on their similarity to the prototype evaluated using vector cosines (the standard similarity measurement for DSMs and Pantel (2010))). We argue that this method is not optimal for the characterization of roles. Distribution vectors are typically constructed as contextual representations, and they contextualize different perceptions. By building the prototype as the center of a vector and measuring the thematic fit with vector cosines, the plausibility is inevitably influenced by many contexts that are irrelevant.

sections.heading: 3.3 Filtering the Contexts
sections.text: Filtering the prototype dimensions by syntactical criteria could be useful in improving our role representations. Indeed, it is reasonable to assume that predicates that interact with the typical patients of a verb are more relevant to characterizing its patient role than, say, prepositional supplements, since they correspond with other actions that are typically performed with the same patients. Imagine that apple, pizza, cake, etc. are some of the most prominent fillers for the OBJ slot you need to eat, and that OBJ-1: Slice-v, OBJ-1: Eat-v, SBJ: Kidn, INSTRUMENT: Fork-n, LOCATION: Table-n are some of the most prominent contexts of the prototype. 9 things that are typically sliced and / or devoured are more likely to be good fillers for the patient role, than the things located on a table.

sections.heading: 3.4 Computing the Thematic Fit
sections.text: Our hypothesis is that fillers whose alienated vector has a large overlap with the prototype representation should have a high thematic fit accuracy. Such overlap should take into account not only the number of common features, but also their respective ranks in the highlighted vectors. sections.heading: 5.1 Error Analysis
sections.text: We performed an error analysis to verify - for the best settings of WO in each dataset - the correlation between vector cosine and WO values (see Table 5) and the peculiarities of the entries with the strongest and weakest correlation (see Table 4). We also found that WHERE and vector cosine always have a high correlation (i.e. above 0.80), with the highest correlations reported for McRae and Ferretti instruments. Looking at Table 4, we can also find the following: • the average gold value of the 35 most (4.65) and least (4.56) correlated items is not significantly different from the average gold value calculated on the complete datasets (4.31), meaning that the distribution of probable and unlikely fillers among the best and worst correlated items is similar to that in the datasets (i.e. no distortion can be identified on the full datasets); both are likely to have the same measurement values among the best and worst correlated items (i.e., no distortion can be identified).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced an uncontrolled distribution method for modelling predictor adaptation judgments based exclusively on syntactical information, inspired by cognitive and psycholinguistic insights, which consists of: i) extracting and filtering the most prominent second-order contexts for each verb-specific role, i.e. the most prominent semantic dimensions of typical verb-specific role fillers; and ii) estimating the thematic adaptation as a weighted overlap between the peak characteristics of the candidate fillers and the prototypes. Once tested on some popular datasets of thematic adaptation judgments, our method consistently exceeds a baseline that re-implements the thematic adaptation model of Baroni and Lenci (2010) as a weighted overlap between the peak characteristics of the candidate fillers and the prototypes, and proves to be competitive, it even requires the best performance on the ferreti-based instruments and the second-best fit set.
